titlepage.titleproper:

Walter Jarocki Photographs, 1937, 1948, 1952-1959, 1970s-early 1980s
titlepage.author:
Finding aid created by
Thomas E. Powers, 1996 and Olga Virakhovskaya, 2013

did.abstract: Hamtramck, Michigan, commercial photographer who took photographs for the city during the administration of Mayor Albert J. Zak in the 1950s. Photonegatives, mostly dated between 1952 and 1958, of public work projects (such as laying of sidewalks), ceremonial functions (such as Christmas displays on city streets), and some political activities. The collection also includes views of the city, its downtown area, residential streets and alleyways behind residences. There are two photographs of Frank Murphy (approximately 1937) and Harry Truman (approximately 1948) visiting Hamtramck. Also a smaller group of photonegatives from the 1970s-early 1980s depicting activities of mayor Robert W. Kozaren, his office, and Hamtramck's daily life.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was the gift of Judge Don Binkowski (donor no. 5501) and came to the library in January 1987.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Walter Jarocki Photographs, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Walter "Flash" Jarocki was commercial photographer and the Hamtramck, Michigan. He served in the Coast Guard during World War II, then spent 20 years with the Hamtramck Fire Department, 6 of them as the Fire Marshall. In the 1950s he photographed and reported for the Hamtramck's newspaper The Citizen and for the mayor's office. In 1960 Jarocki moved to Tarpon Springs, Florida. In 1972-1980s he worked as a reporter and photographer for Tampa's WTVT television station.

One of his most important clients in the 1950s was the city of Hamtramck itself: its citizens, businesses, schools, and its leaders, such as mayor Albert J. Zak. Albert Zak, "the man with the plan for Hamtramck," was elected mayor in 1952 on promises of better recreation and health programs, slum clearance, more jobs, and clean streets and alleys. Zak opposed loans and raises for city employees, while financing continuous street-sweeping and paving of city alleys at the expense of the pension fund. In 1963 Zak took an appointment with Wayne County and resigned as Hamtramck's Mayor. He was re-elected mayor in 1974, having appealed to voters' desire for stability on the campaign trail, but died in office the following year. In the 1950s Jarocki took hundreds of photographs during Zak's administration, chronicling the official activities of the mayor and the accomplishments of the city government. Jarocki also took photographs of Hamtramck's citizens, sports teams, businesses, public events, street views, etc. for the Hamtramck Citizen newspaper.

In 1980 Robert W. Kozaren was elected the Hamtramck mayor, to become the longest-served mayor in the city's history (1980-1997). During Kozaren's tenure a General Motors assembly plant was built in Hamtramck, as well as the William Dickerson Detention Facility. The city also gained in population in the 1990s.

scopecontent.p: The Walter "Flash" Jarocki photograph collection includes photonegatives and two oversize photoprints and organized into three series: Walter "Flash" Jarocki, "Gordie," and Unknown photographer.

The Walter "Flash" Jarocki series (approximately 2265 photonegatives and 2 oversize photoprints; 1937, 1948 and 1952-1959) is the heart of the collection. The majority of images taken by Jarocki are those of mayor Zak at public events and a number of private gatherings; also images depicting Hamtramck public work projects, ceremonial functions, athletic events, political campaigns, public meetings and social gatherings. The series includes numerous views of the city, its downtown area, residential streets, and alleyways behind the residences. A number of images depict the city of Milan, Mich. leaders, events, and images. Also found in the series are two photoprints, one of an earlier date featuring Frank Murphy shaking hands with Mayor Rudolph Tenerowicz, most likely taken in 1937; the other is a photograph of President Truman, probably taken during the 1948 campaign, and being greeted by Hamtramck dignitaries. Photonegatives in this series are stored in original envelopes with descriptions of events, names of people, date, and time(s) of the day when images were taken. Container list in this finding aid reflects only main subject of images. Researchers may find more detailed descriptions on envelopes.

scopecontent.p: The "Gordie" series (approximately 100 photonegatives; 1970s-1980s) takes its name from the name "Gordie" inscribed across five envelopes. One of the original envelopes was titled and dated "St. Ladislaus basketball game, March 1971"; the rest of the envelopes are numbered as they were found in the collection (Envelopes 1-4). Researchers will find description of subjects of photonegatives in these envelopes in the container list. Untitled and undated photonegatives in envelopes 1-4 depict Hamtramck's daily life and include images of school children, views of classrooms, school athletic events and athletic teams, street scenes, offices, businesses, a wedding, and portraits of individuals; also images of Hamtramck's mayor Robert Kozaren with others.

The Unknown Photographer series (approximately 70 photonegatives; 1970s-1980s) contains one original envelope bearing crossed out names "Gordie" and "Mitch," containing photonegatives with images similar to those in the "Gordie" series: school children, athletic events, street views, mayor Kozaren, portraits, etc. Also included in this series are photonegatives that were found loose in the collection: group photos, street scenes, athletic teams and events, etc.
